James Dewitt Yancey "J Dilla"

Rapper and Producer - The Legend of Underground Hip-Hop

Timeline of J Dilla's Life

  • 1974 - Born in Detroit, Michigan to Maureen Yancey, a famous Opera singer, and Beverely Yancey, a jazz bassist who performed at half-time shows for several years.
  • 1992 - Met Amp Fiddler, a famous musician Detroit, who helped him master the Akai MPC.
  • 1995 - Formed group 1st Down, the first Detroit hip-hop group to sign with a major label, with MC Phat Kat. Group disbanded soon after due to label trouble.
  • 1996 - Formed group Slum Village and recorded Fantastic, Vol. 1 with RJ Rice Studios.
  • 2000-2001 - Released Fantastic, Vol. 2. He also produced for musicians like Erykah Badu, Poe, Talib Kweli, and Common. One of his largest contributions, though not the least, led to the well known album Like Water for Cholocate.
  • 2002 - Signed a solo deal with MCA Records and began working on a rap album. Though having a variety of producers on his album, such as Madlib, Pete Rock, Hi-Tek and more; the album was shelved due to changes at MCA.
  • 2006 - Released final album Donuts. Days after, passed away in his home in Los Angeles, California following cardiac arrest.
"Trust me. I tell everybody it's better to do it yourself and let the indies come after you instead of going their way and getting a deal and you have to wait. It ain't fun. Take it from me. Right now, I'm on MCA, but it feels like I'm an unsigned artist still. It's cool. It's a blessing, but damn I'm like, 'When's my shit gonna come out? I'm ready now, what's up?" -- J Dilla

To learn more about the legacy of J Dilla and the way his music still shapes hip-hop, and the music scene overall, visit his Wikipedia Page.
